body_html:
The Windows failures were bugging me, so I stuck a test in gcc.godbolt.org:

https://godbolt.org/g/dkqoLs

There's a call to a built-in vectorized __vdecl_sinf4 sin function. If you decrease N to 3 it will call sinf instead. Seems like MSVC is auto-vectorizing our code with even crappier trigonometric implementations.
body_text:
The Windows failures were bugging me, so I stuck a test in gcc.godbolt.org:
https://godbolt.org/g/dkqoLs
There's a call to a built-in vectorized __vdecl_sinf4 sin function. If you decrease N to 3 it will call sinf instead. Seems like MSVC is auto-vectorizing our code with even crappier trigonometric implementations.
body:
The Windows failures were bugging me, so I stuck a test in `gcc.godbolt.org`:

https://godbolt.org/g/dkqoLs

There's a call to a built-in vectorized `__vdecl_sinf4` sin function. If you decrease `N` to `3` it will call `sinf` instead. Seems like MSVC is auto-vectorizing our code with even crappier trigonometric implementations.
